content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.A study was conducted with <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to investigate whether yawning is contagious. Each volunteer was randomly assigned to one of two groups: Group A or Group B. Each person in Group A was shown a video in which someone yawned, and each person in Group B was shown a video in which no one yawned. Of the <math alttext="34" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>34</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people assigned to Group A, <math alttext="11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> yawned, and of the <math alttext="16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people assigned to Group B, <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> yawned.(a) Is this study an observational study or an experiment? Explain your choice in context.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.A study was conducted with <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to investigate whether yawning is contagious. Each volunteer was randomly assigned to one of two groups: Group A or Group B. Each person in Group A was shown a video in which someone yawned, and each person in Group B was shown a video in which no one yawned. Of the <math alttext="34" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>34</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people assigned to Group A, <math alttext="11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> yawned, and of the <math alttext="16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people assigned to Group B, <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> yawned.(a) Is this study an observational study or an experiment? Explain your choice in context.

Let <math alttext="p sub uppercase A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the proportion of all people who would yawn when shown the video in which someone yawned, and let <math alttext="p sub uppercase B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the proportion of all people who would yawn when shown the video in which no one yawned. (b) Explain why it is inappropriate to use a two-sample <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for proportions to test the following hypotheses. <math alttext="For H sub 0, p sub uppercase A equals p sub uppercase B. For H sub lowercase a, p sub uppercase A is greater than p sub uppercase B." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

(c) Based on the study data, determine the point estimate for <math alttext="p sub uppercase A, minus p sub uppercase B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math>. Show your work.

(d) A simulation to approximate the sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions <math alttext="p hat, sub uppercase A, minus p hat, sub uppercase B" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math> was conducted under the assumption that yawning is not contagious. The graph shows the results of <math alttext="1,000" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> trials of such a simulation. (i) Based on your answer in part (c) and the simulated results, what is the approximate <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value for the test stated in part (b)? Show your work. (ii) Based on your answer to part (d-i) and using a significance level of <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what conclusion is appropriate about whether yawning is contagious? Justify your answer.
